page.title: 17CLAYTON TUNNEL
page.content: The London-Brighton railway line which runs northward through the block passes under the Downs through Clayton Tunnel, almost 2 km long, and emerges at Clayton Village. In 1841 the Tunnel was finished. The route through the Downs was the idea of Sir John Rennie. It cost Â£4O,OOO per mile, involving the tunnel with its tudor fortress folly as the tunnel keeper's house. In 1861 there was the Clayton Tunnel disaster. Two trains collided. 24 were killed, 2OO injured. New morse signalling procedures nationwide were set up as a result of this. The folly at the end of the tunnel is still inhabited. The occupier enjoys living there and claims that she is not disturbed by the continuous traffic beneath her. Her main problem is access to clean her windows. Many sightseers stop to view the folly.
